## Concatenate elements

```{r}
text <- 'awesome'
paste("R is",text)
```

```{r}
text1 <- "R is"
text2 <- "awesome"
paste(text1,text2)
```
### If we try to combine a string and a number, we will get error:
```{r}
num <- 5
text <- "some text"
num + text
```

### hence we can use paste() method :
```{r}
num <- 5
text <- "some text"
paste(num,text)
```

## Data Types

* numeric :- (15, 13.4, 465)
* integer :- (1L, 27L, 104L, where the letter 'L' is present is integer )
* complex :- (9 + 3i, where 'i' is imaginary part )
* character :- (aka: string) :- ("ajay", "v", "12"... )
* logical :- (aka: boolean) :- (TRUE or FALSE/ T or F)

```{r}

class(12.5)
class(15L)

```

## Strings

### Multiline string

```{r}
str <- "Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet,
consectetur adipiscing elit,
sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt
ut labore et dolore magna aliqua."

str
```
``` This will add "\n" to every line break following can be used to get rid of it ```

``` Using cat() function :```
```{r}
str <- "Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet,
consectetur adipiscing elit,
sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt
ut labore et dolore magna aliqua."

cat(str)
```
### String Length

```{r}
str <- "Hello world!"
nchar(str)
```

### Check a String 

``` Use the grepl() function to check if a character or a sequence of characters are present in a string: ```

```{r}
str <- "Hello World!"
grepl("H",str)
grepl("World",str)
grepl("HELLO",str)
```
### Combine Two strings

```{r}
str1 <- "hello"
str2 <- "world"
paste(str1,str2)
```

## R Escape Characters
``` An escape character is a backslash \ followed by the character you want to insert.```

``` Following statement will give error because we are using " " inside " "
```{r}
str <- "We are the so-called "Vikings", from the north."
str
```

``` To fix this problem, use the escape character \": ```

```{r}
str <- "We are so-called \"Vikings\", from the north."
cat(str)
```

## Other escape characters in R:
```
* \\    Backslash
* \n    New line
* \r    Carriage Return
* \t    Tab
* \b    Backspace
```


```{r}
str <- "This is the example of using a backslash : \\ "
cat(str)

str1 <- "\n\nThis is the example of \nusing new line "
cat(str1)

```
```{r}
str <- "this \r is the example of using carriage return: "
str
cat(str)
```

```{r}
str <- "this is the \texample of tab"
cat(str)
```

```{r}
str <- "this is the\b example of backspace"
str
cat(str)
```

## Operators

```
* Arithmetic Operators
  + Addition            +
  + Subtraction         -
  + Multiplication      *
  + Division            /
  + Exponent            ^
  + Modulus             %%
  + Integer Division    %/%
  
  
* Comparison Operators
  + Equal                      ==
  + Not equal                  !=
  + greater than               >
  + less than                  <
  + greater then or equal to   >=
  + less then or equal to      <=



* Logical Operators
  + &   
  + &&
  + |
  + ||
  + !
  
  
* Miscellaneous Operators
  + :       create a series of numbers in a sequence    x <- 1:10
  + %in%    Find out if an element belongs to a vector  x %in% y
  + %*%     matrix multiplication                       x <- Matrix1 %*% Matrix2
```

## If... Else

```{r}
a <- 20
b <- 30

if (b > a)
{
  print("b is Greater than a")
}
```
```R uses curly brackets { } to define the scope in the code.```

## else if and else

```{r}
a <- 300
b <- 30

if(b > a) {
  print("b is greater than a")
} else if(a == b) {
  print("a and b are equal")
} else {
  print("a is greater than b")
}
```

``` Note that 'else if' should always be written immediately after end of if block``` 


## Nested If Statements

```You can also have if statements inside if statements, this is called nested if statements.```

```{r}

x <- 11
if(x > 10) {
  print("Above 10")
  if(x > 20) {
    print("And also above 20")
  } else {
    print("But not above 20")
  }
} else {
  print("below 10")
}
```

## While Loop 


```{r}
i <- 1
while(i < 6) {
  print(i)
  i <- i + 1
}
```

``` In while loop we can also use 'break' to break the normal flow of the code even if the condition is TRUE. ```

```In while loops we can also use 'next' statement to skip an iteration without terminating the loop.```

```{r}
i <- 0
while (i < 6) {
  i <- i + 1
  if (i == 3) {
    next
  }
  print(i)
}
```
